pros:
I decided to work in this field because I believe everyone should have the opportunity to live their life and achieve their goals regardless of their abilities. About 2 weeks in to training, I got COVID and my nightmare began. My managers HARASSED ME by calling me several times to make sure I was really sick (I could barely speak). 
After I returned back to work, I became upper managements punching bag. They gaslighted me and scolded me on mistakes in the notes because I wasn't properly trained. They only care about MONEY. Their mission statement is nothing but a facade. Staff is overworked and poorly compensated. We cannot go over 40 hours a week yet some of us have to make up 100+ hours with clients that were not in program due to Covid (and somehow this is our fault?) This company is disgusting, money hungry and toxic.
cons:
Poor pay (after working 30+ hours a week and after taxes and benefits, I take home barely enough to pay for smaller bills let alone my rent)
Disgusting favoritism
Passive aggressive behavior from upper management
Poor work/life balance (don't you DARE have kids or other responsibilities after work. You are a slave and must devote your whole life to this job)
Slave labor (a lot of day support staff support clients at their jobs. Some of these individuals are simply not capable of doing certain tasks which requires their staff to do 95% of the work without being compensated by the company the client works for. That's borderline illegal)
AND MUCH MORE!!!

review_title: Great pay, but toxic workplace environment
pros: The pay for a Behavioral interventionist starts at $20 an hour. Flexible hours but beware of over scheduling (can be severely overworked). Working with children living with ASD was really rewarding. You learn a lot about how people with ASD learn and how to track their development.
cons: Management and scheduling team are horrible. The company likes to promote that they work well with college students, but that is an absolute lie. They demand a week long training from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM. As a college student I had to notify all my professors that I would be absent for a whole week. They denied changes in my availability and I had to wait three months before I could change it again (and it was a small change). They can schedule you 24 hours in advance with no warning, so if you don't keep the iPad (which they give you) on your person at all times you could miss something. I went several weeks without data sheets, even when I asked for more several times. They encourage participant development be tracked on a notebook piece of paper when you run out of data sheets which is completely unprofessional.

review_title: I once never felt appreciated throughout my 2.5 years.
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Des Moines, IA
pros:
Relatively flexible job. 

Lots of the clients are fun, friendly and exciting to work with
cons:
I've never felt appreciated at this job. I was asked to come in early, give up shifts, take overtime, etc. CONSTANTLY. This was not a full-time job where I could expect a stable income. I had management call me and cancel my shifts less than 12 hours before I was supposed to be there multiple times. I budgeted on working that shift and getting that pay but I got nothing. I also have multiple times shown up to shifts to work with clients and nobody is home and I call the "on-call" and they tell me to go home because they forgot to tell me the client didn't need services today. Even though I spent 30 mins driving to the site and drove 20 miles, Easterseals refused to reimburse me for any of that. Not only did I waste my time and my gas, but I also was expecting to be paid for that shift and there was never an opportunity to make up that money.

Easterseals will nickel-and-dime you for EVERYTHING. Easterseals management will make a mistake and expect you to pocket the expense. Easterseals will forgo your bonuses and forgo your raises because of a new project they are working on. Meanwhile, Easterseals is sending you an email almost weekly bragging about another tens of thousands of dollar donation they received. To make matters worse, Easterseals will hound you about donating to their mission (20 dollars or more is recommended). As an employee in an industry where people make 12-15 an hour, I am not volunteering my time or donating more than my hourly pay.

While working at Easterseals, I received the bare minimum in training. Once I subbed at a site that needed a staff and Easterseals gave me two hours of training before they left me on the cite alone. It was HELL. The clients had to teach me how to do their care routines and I was so stressed but was told to suck it up because it was an "emergency." This was so unsafe. It makes me wonder why Easterseals is always bragging about opening new cites when they consistently have to pull staff who are not trained to work at other houses. Similarly, I always worked the morning shift at a house and was asked to stay and work the evening shift as well. I told management I didn't feel comfortable because I had never been taught or shown how to put the clients to bed. Management told me to ask the client and the clients would teach me how to do it. How can Easterseals claim to be client focused when they are failing to train staff on how to take care of the clients.

Throughout my time at Easterseals, there was only one time the management ever came to the 24 hour houses I worked at. Many of the clients at the 24-hour houses would complain about the management failing to actually implement the care plans made by the case managers. Managers would rather 24-hour staff leave the houses and put the clients on alone time so the staff can go pick up cleaning supplies, masks, technology, etc. from the office then the managers step foot outside the office and bring those necessary items to the sites. Multiple times I had to leave clients who could not use the bathroom independently alone for 30+ mins because the managers didn't want to visit the 24-hour houses to drop off needed supplies. It is obvious the managers put their comfort above the quality of life for many of these clients.

Overall, based on my experience, I do not recommend that anyone place there loved-one in an Easterseals home. There are multiple other companies that are more competent and actually train their employees. Many other companies take their responsibilities as a company to provide care seriously, but from my experience, Easterseals does not.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Bernardino, CA
pros: As a Behavioral Interventionist (BI), very often one can feel overwhelmed with the cases, families, schedule, and mostly the driving. However, it can be very rewarding depending on your level of patience and love for the job. The upside to this job is that there is always opportunities to move up, but it will require a Master's degree for certain positions like a Program Manager or Clinical Supervisor. During the pandemic, Easterseals in my opinion really took care of their employees in terms of compensation, safety, and updates. In addition, being assigned to a clinical team makes the job of a BI easier and more efficient; it also makes it a little bit more intimate (so it's not intimidating to seek for help & support when/if needed). Overall, it's a good job, especially if you are curious about the ABA field. It's challenging, but extremely rewarding.
cons: The downside of working as a Behavioral Interventionist (BI) (at least in Easterseals) is that it can be extremely overwhelming. The families you would be assigned to can sometimes be draining. The cases can be emotionally tiring. The drive especially can be dreadful. Saying all this also if you are not really into the job to begin with (yes you will feel those things regardless if you love the job or not — but you would definitely feel it more if you don't). As a BI, this job is actually rewarding in a way that your hard work many times can be seen in the progress of the client you're working with and the smiles and excitement of the families when progress is seen. Something to consider also is that this job requires major flexibility with your time; this is something that took me a while to get used to because when your prime case is cancelled for the day, it will be expected that you will make up that time either that same day or another day with another case (sometimes new). Sometimes it may feel like your time isn't yours due to scheduling flexibility to move you around whenever and wherever. Again, this is something I had to get used to coming from a working environment that was a little bit more consistent on a day-to-day basis. In addition, it takes a while for a schedule change to process, which is a big deal if you're a student and or if life just happens. And because of this I think the biggest downside has more to do with schedule/scheduling protocols than anything else.

pros:
- The non-management staff are almost all really great. They're so nice and hardworking, and they really make a difference in people's lives.
- The location is pretty nice, there's almost always plenty of parking, it's not in a super-crowded area.
- The pay is good, especially for a non-profit
- The clients are awesome. It's great coming to work and making a real difference for people.
cons:
Management is a huge problem, and all top levels of management are questionable, at best. Most (if not all) of the executive team have no experience with or connection to disability services, and it shows in choices for programming and fundraising. 

The overall direction of the company is extremely unfocused, and as a result, some of the most valuable staff are under-utilized and over-worked. There is a culture of people giving the appearance of being extremely busy while avoiding well thought out, planned work. This may be different in different departments, though.

The culture of the organization as a whole is not especially welcoming or inclusive, and there is almost no mission connection. Many administrative staff actually seem bothered or irritated when interacting with clients with disabilities.

There are several formal programs in place for employee recognition, which is nice, but the day-to-day experience is extremely different. Questions are usually not welcome, and mind-reading is usually required, despite management repeatedly verbally insisting the opposite.

The benefits are eh, but that's to be expected at a non-profit. There's currently no retirement plan in place.

pros: The job is simple and often stress free. Easily able to get more hours when desired or take off depending on the house and shift. Able to flex schedule, good for school. For the most part you have free reign during your shift. Likes to do gatherings for consumers and staff.
cons: You work alone mostly. Must work 8 holidays a year. Pay is not great and based on you level of education. Not easy to move up in the company. Management not very supportive. Co-workers can be catty. Most co-workers have no background in mental health and therefore do not understand the diagnosis or medications. Depending on the house, you may have to remain if relief doesn't come (due to emergencies or just lateness). If there is an emergency situation you may have to remain at work for paperwork. It is very very easy to get a med error (errors are on a point system of 3 to 5, 11 point equals termination, points are only removed after months of no errors). If a consumer or consumers family has an issue with staff (regardless of the reason) most often management will remove that staff from the house and send them to a different facility. During times of harsh weather (ie: snow storms), coworkers often call out. Consumers are often not appropriately admitted and management will play favorites with consumers.

pros: They give you an iPad and a cell phone. They pay you to log in your hours. They pay you $300 for taking a class relevant to your job and attaining an A.  Pay is slightly higher than most companies.
cons: There's a lack of guidance from program managers and require you to be on-call. Kaiser demands that kids show progress within two weeks or they take away services from insurance. This puts a lot of pressure on interventionists. There's also lack of understanding from management if you're sick, you've been in a car accident, or your family member is in the hospital. A year later, when they evaluate how much you'll be designated in your raise, they will cite absences from when you are sick or when you've been in a car accident as reason to give you a lower raise. It can be as low as 20 cents an hour.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: They paid me when I was supposed to be and PTO benefits were generous.
cons: I worked as a manager at the St. Louis/ESMW Midwest branch for several years. Staff turnover was a constant issue (2/3 of new staff quitting in the first couple months) Basic training is focused on getting staff trained and working as fast as possible, not training them well so people get frustrated and quit. So you need staff and train them as quickly as possible and the cycle repeats. For staff that do stick around there is no accountability so they can just refuse to do their jobs and know they wont be fired because staff are needed so desperately.  To make matters worse, directors will continue to take on new clients when there isn’t the staff to support them. Almost all feed back is what you are doing wrong and rarely will you get a genuine ‘thank you.’  Morale is non-existent and Ive observed directors openly bad mouth other team members on multiple occasions. I’ve been gaslighted several times when trying to address issues with lack of training and support.   Once you hit management level (and are salaried) you’ll need to work 40+ hours a week just to keep you head above water and there’s little room for advancement. 60+ hours are common, especially with residential services.

review_title: Clients are the lowest priority compared to funding and growth.
pros: Working with clients and families is rewarding and the reason I started working in residential treatment. For what staff are paid and expected to do, they generally preform at an excellent level.
cons:
Healthcare is too expensive compared to wages. Most direct care employees cannot afford to see their doctor or fill their prescriptions due to the rise in cost of our new self funded healthcare plan. 

Supervisors and managers are expected to work long hours, be on call 24/7, cover shifts for sick or vacationing employees, keep overtime to nearly zero. 

Overall organization priorities are on fundraising and expansion while direct services suffer. Employes feel alienated from the mission of providing high quality community integration and building independent skills. The administration is bloated with resources and titles and neglect the people that provide their services and their clients. Upper management, who decides the mission and goals of the homes, are never on sight and lack the direct experience to form well rounded organizational decisions. There is a culture of secrecy. Important information is not discriminated in a timely manner until it is a crisis situation and then expect supervisors and direct service providers to react immediately. 

This is honestly the worst run direct service organization that I have ever worked for.

review_title: Poor overall management - Camp: Rocky Mountain Village, Empire CO
pros:
The campers & clients are a joy 
It is really nice to live where you work especially when you put in the hours that I did :)
cons: The camp directors are incredibly unprofessional.  Neither have a formal education nor professional work experience.  It is great that they have landed good jobs however, due to their lack of leadership experience they make the number one mistake of new managers; they are authoritarian, suspicious  and over delegate.  They are extremely defensive of feedback.  They lead by intimidation and the folks who do stay for more than two years have extremely passive personalities.  To get a long at Rocky Mountain Village Easter Seals Camp you must be able to work independently, there is no team, no training, not even help answering questions but there is a lot of criticism  if you do something wrong.   My direct supervisor performed my job for over two years before hiring me to take over several pieces of his job responsibility.  Whenever I asked for systems, best practices, leads....etc, he would say, "I don't know".  I had to start the tasks from absolute start although there must have been some systems set up at one time.

review_title: Prepare to feel like you’re doing everything
pros: No regrets working here. Easter seals helped me realize a lot of personal strengths and weaknesses. I have met and worked with some amazing people.
cons:
for management: I was an assistant manager to no manager..meaning I was doing all the work of a program manager but getting paid as the assistant manager due to “no room in the budget” for me to have the title and pay. When you’re in management, you also never leave work because it will follow you everywhere. Your life becomes Easter seals that you forget what else is happening in the world because a personal life is non existent. 

DSA: you will be pressured to cover shifts to eventually becoming burnt out from overworking..

It all depends where they put you within any of their programs. There are positives and cons but this place, I feel is a stepping stone for people in terms of experience into a career.

pros: Easter Seals has a wonderful mission. The benefits and time off at Easterseals are great.
cons: A great mission but terrible management!!! The management over the finance department is very disconnected from the day-to-day realities of the finance personnel. The impression I have witnessed with regards to management of the finance department is that they care more about the image of themselves, and their self-serving agendas. The benefits and time off at Easterseals are great, but you don't benefit from it if you are asked to come in on your requested days off or is not allowed to take time off. If you are looking for a work life balance...forget it! Working 60 hour weeks and some weekends was the norm for me. When I mentioned my workload concerns to upper management, I was told to take it or leave it and that I am a salaried employee and should be working 50-55 hours or more weekly. Working for Easterseals starts off leaving you feeling inspired, but ends with you feeling used and unappreciated. If you like being overworked, underpaid, and constantly stressed out about unreasonable expectations and deadlines, then this is the company for you! Good luck!!!

job_title: Mental Health Outpatient Therapist in Mount Airy, NC
pros: This company is strongly committed to providing high quality services for the individuals in the various communities they are in.  Their primary source of reimbursement is Medicare, Medicaid,, NC Health Choice and BCBS. They are a non-profit and are working hard to balance their bottom line so as to be able to continue to provide services.
cons: ESUCP of NC and VA  has focused more so on community based services and personal care services.  They do not have a history of offering pay raises.  In recent years they moved their outpatient MH therapists from salaried positions to hourly paid positions, so unless a client was present for outpatient therapy the clinician was paid less, sometimes at minimum wage for clinical documentation or maintenance of the medical record as required by various payors.

review_title: Easter Seals Steals Your Soul and Talents
job_title: Service Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Some flexibility - because the organization is constantly creating new policy and making radical changes it is frustrating to deliver on unrealistic expectations and no measurable goals to the coordinators.  Promotion is done by default - who ever is able to stay the longest and under-perform with no real training and good at having poor communication with staff. Across the board the worst nonprofit for dedicated people, but if you are lazy, low performing and can push blame easily this could work for someone who just needs a job.
cons: Terrible office culture with poor employee work ethics on supervisory and management levels.  Even though they enjoy making rules that change daily, it is counter productive to the population it is trying to serve.  The Southern California  Service Coordinating Management enjoy wasting half of the day socializing and push required tasks to others by not taking responsibility or accountability for work on a daily basis. Revolving door of staff and employees are sent out of the organization like a magic trick never to be seen or heard of again. It is unfortunate because it is a needed service for families with disabilities and they fail daily on providing low quality service with subpar and minimal support.

pros: Time spent with clients was awesome.
cons: Program manager, supervisor and staff!

review_title: Employed 14 years. Was an Individual habilitation plan coordinator. Position cut, stepped down to direct care last 5 yrs
job_title: Direct Support Professional in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great if you enjoy assisting people with special needs. Hours are eight am to 4pm with weekends off. Twenty personal paid days per year accrued monthly.
cons: Health benefits are being eliminated and those who are still eligible pay dearly. Average benefit deduction $350 per month for parent with one child. Company no longer values qualified full time staff, only hiring part time so they can phase out benefits. The program cannot provide programs it sells itself on. This puts direct support staff in a difficult position as they are responsible to provide services the company does not provide funding for.

review_title: Okay work if you want to be in social service and can't afford college.
pros: All you need is a GED to be eligible for the job.  Paid training, paid holidays, mileage reimbursement, on-time payments.  There were opportunities for advancement and often people were promoted from within (though the higher-level jobs usually required more than a GED).
cons: The training was two weeks full time, but then almost nothing I learned in the training applied to the work.   I never did receive my CPR certificate from the initial training. It didn't feel like a real job. I picked the client up at his house and drove around 30 hours a week with the client doing things like going to the gym, the library, malls, fast-food restaurants - wherever he wanted to go.  I tried to interact with him and use some of the training, but all he wanted to do was play on his iphone.  I went to the office for monthly meetings and that was about it for contact with the rest of the staff.  The supervisor would respond to text messages but let emails go unanswered.

review_title: The way employees are treated at Goodwill Easter Seals of the Gulf Coast
job_title: Former Store Manager in Mobile, AL
pros: Mission services and assisting people with disabilities
cons: The way employees are treated.There are some who have worked for 10 plus years and don't even make 10.00 per hour.I was a store manager.The executive staff for Gesgc can be very conniving and use cut throat tactics.I have worked for other companies with the same tactics.Never in my wildest dreams did I think a company who does so much for the community would treat their employees as they do.I am not referring to all Easter Seal affiliate s.I can only speak of the Easter Seals affiliate in Mobile Alabama.I will give an example.A donor greeter discovered that some art work donated was valuable.It came to 15,000 dollars.They did nothing for this employee.A comment from a VP was someone should by him lunch.Gesgc has lost touch with the mission and how they treat employees.

review_title: Easter Seals Midwest - Low morale, low pay, little opportunity for growth
pros: Generous Paid Time Off policy
cons: Be aware that Easter Seals affiliates operate independently, so what is true of one affiliate may not be true of another.  Easter Seals Midwest has undergone many changes in recent years due to a merger between Life Skills and TouchPoint Autism Services which ultimately became the Missouri Easter Seals affiliate.  Some employees haven't seen raises in many years yet are being asked to continue taking on more and more responsibility without any acknowledgment of their hard work. Work-life balance is okay for some employees and almost non-existent for others, depending on department.  ESMO has adopted a "wellness" program which requires employees to jump through healthcare hoops in order to qualify for discounted health insurance.  Senior management seems oblivious to the pervasive mood of discontent caused in large part by a punitive culture rather than one which rewards good work.  The burnout is leading to high turnover throughout departments.

pros: Potential to an incredible service for disabled individuals within the community.
cons: Unfortunately it is not. Mismanagement of residential programs in Manchester is overlooked due to lack of funding. The staff can be rude and borderline verbally abusive to one another (rarely to clients). The environment set up in these residential programs are reminiscent of high school cliques. Bullying extends beyond staff within program but from the nurse in charge of the Manchester res. program. Incredibly unprofessional. Many agencies know this to be true which makes listing working here on my resume almost embarrassing, often having to explain my experience. Many staff with write off the turn over rate by saying "It takes a special type of person to work in this kind of field". Implying that the individuals are difficult to work with. This is not the case, it takes a special type of clique like behavior to work at this job. The individuals have little to nothing to do with turn over.

pros: NONE TO SHARE!!! Atleast some employees try to do their job and care about clients but most have their hands tied due to lack of communication or resources.
cons: Hostile working environment. Blame game is high. Minorities are frowned upon and even by VP's been called out on the lack of diversity in the company BUT BLAMES THE DEMOGRAPHICS AND THEIR LACK OF EDUCATION!! Have too much funding so they can waste a lot in order to keep grants. If parents knew what I saw, they would run. As a parent in one of their programs, luckily that location is on point and is FINALLY full staffed.

review_title: Expanded way too quickly and quality of care has continued to sink
pros: I learned a lot while working here, especially early on, because the quality of the program was high and the atmosphere was very team-oriented. When they suddenly had to bulk up staffing to fulfill a huge new contract with Kaiser, though, things began to unravel.
cons: No sense of community. High turnover. Inadequate training - specifically hiring inexperienced Behavioral Interventionists who did not receive enough training or ongoing support and guidance. Benefits and starting pay were also cut during this time. The review process was disorganized and inaccurate, relying on feedback on the quality of my work from a supervisor who never observed me or responded to my emails or phone calls about the case we worked on together.

pros: I truly enjoy working with the senior population in residential care. Some of my clients are the sweetest people that I have had the pleasure to work for. Also, my manager and the other ladies within the office are awesome and are willing to work with you for your scheduling.
cons: The cons are no opportunity to advance or offer of a full time position. I am currently a part time-on call worker and do not like that status as they can call you whenever they feel like it. The raises are kind of pathetic at 5 or 10 cents, after being there a year or more. No benefits for part time employees and of course the normal wear and tear of your vehicle for having to drive all over the place. I would only recommend this job to someone who is looking to make an extra income because the pay is too low to make this your only job.

job_title: ABA Therapist in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I'm at Easterseals Midwest at St. Louis, Autism Services Department. The work culture is genuinely positive - employees and supervisors put in extra effort to appreciate strengths and growth, both in employees and the children we work with. Supervisors enthusiastic and dedicated to the mission of improving kids' wellbeing.

There's a variety of environments to work in (summer treatment program, schools, in-home) and a range of ages   (I've worked with younger than 3 to ~10 years old).

My supervisor comes to observe my sessions once a week, helpful feedback. Takes my observations and suggestions into consideration - feels like we're working together, not just like they're dictating to me what I should do. Always changing the treatment plan to better support and help the kids we work with.
cons:
Pay is $13/hour starting rate which can be unsustainable. But management and trainings are transparent about finances - it's mostly to do with limited government funding.

Burnout and stressful situations definitely happen, but supervisors and coworkers are very supportive, very happy to debrief about it and make changes if needed.

pros: I really enjoy being a therapist and having a reputable company/brand to work with. I enjoyed working with my fellow co-workers and support staff.  I really do care for my clients and find the job to be quite fulfilling at times.
cons: Unbelievable amounts of paperwork, high caseloads, management that has little to no compassion, mgt. does not involve its amazingly talented clinical staff in ways to manage our workloads better.  Burnout is high leading to high-turnover in clinical staff.  This ultimately hurts the client, whom we all took an oath to "do no harm" to :(

review_title: Helping the community, but not their employees.  Left for more professional environment.
pros: Flexibility is great. Decent benefits.  A good stepping stone to other employment in the community....you have the opportunity to network with other agencies to help your clients and they get to know you and eventually want to hire you.  Continuing education classes are encouraged.  Laid back office environment.  Good upper management, but you rarely see them.
cons: Very low starting salary (usually around $28K, even for college grads).  Little room to ever move up.  Local management is a joke and is degrading to employees (requirement:  thick skin).  The redundant documentation is ridiculous.  Retirement benefits are low, compared with other companies.  Office moral is low.

review_title: Soul crushing but an experience that will shape outlook forever
pros: Opportunity to take on a lot of responsibility within an entry level position. Working with some amazing people and families at the different schools and programs. Very rewarding work at times.
cons:
Pay is laughable (yes, I know it's a nonprofit) especially for the location. The offices were below working standards, again, even for a nonprofit.  It seems as though Easter Seals is a front for the pyramid scheme, Amway. The many great people were outshined by the shady characters that passed through the board and staff over the years. Nonprofits are typically understaffed so work life balance is not as great as one may assume and capable employees often did 3+ jobs and then also took on the work load of non-capable employees. As a results the work environment often was quite stressful, overwhelming and disorganized. 
However, most of the good people are now long gone anyway. I feel terrible for the few that are still left. Success was also measured in a very antiquated way. The little data and financial information we did have access to was always a mess.

job_title: Behavior Therapist in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-free meals if you could attend monthly meetings
- opportunity to work with children and families
cons:
- low pay
- management and scheduling does not care about you
-threaten to fire you  via occurences often if you take a day off for emergency reasons 
-i would not recommenced this place to work
- no compensation for an accident that happened during driving to a client
- too demanding and too many rules
- you cant accept any food from clients, cant be their early, cant give them to much info of progress, 
-not enough support from PM &CS and a lot of times they were condescending especially CS''s
-not a livable wage, too many cancellations from families
- if you ever become full time you need to work 37.5 hours for 3 months without cancellations which is almost impossible due to cancellations

pros: Pay is higher than most companies. Start off at $16/hr. You truly do feel like you're making a difference in a child's life. Yearly raises depending on performance.
cons:
You are expected to not have any other commitments, which would be fine, if Easter Seals provided its employees with substantial hours.  I worked for another behavior therapy company and they were much less strict when I was unable to sub for a session due to my schedule with Easter Seals.

You are also not expected to be sick. After a year, you will be evaluated and your absences, despite being due to sickness or car accidents acquired from being on the job, will prohibit you from attaining a raise.

If you do not enroll in the national university's master's program, there is no way to move up in your title.

review_title: Easter Seals is a poor work environment (Autism Therapeutic School - not sure about other programs).
pros: A fantastic opportunity to help people with disabilities. The students really need help from concerned and dedicated staff. This is a career field where individuals can make a difference.
cons: Poor or nonexistent communication with management. If someone says something negative about another employee to management, there is no effort on the part of management to hear "the other side of the story".  It's just assumed that what is said is true. No advancement opportunities. Junior personnel are expected to be seen but not heard. If an employee is accepted into the "in crowd" he/she can do no wrong to include chronic late to work and excessive sick days.  All others are kept on a short leash.

pros: Honestly, nothing beneficial whatsoever has become of the position I accepted with this company. So many promises were made, and I believed it all, but accepting this position has been the biggest regret of my life.
cons: Management has no idea what they're doing. It's like everyone is on their first day. They promise health benefits, high hourly pay, "near full-time" hours, but none of it every happened. I accepted a full time job to work for this company, and they have a company policy of scheduling at least 10 hours per week, but they gave me 6. I literally had to go on welfare to feed my family. I haven't been able to find other work, so after being here nearly a year, I am financially ruined. So many promises that things will be added to my schedule but it never happens. Terrible company.

review_title: Compassionate and ethical ABA provider. Constantly growing and evolving.
job_title: Clinical Supervisor, BCBA in San Diego, CA
pros: Easter Seals is the largest ABA provider in California and works exclusively with Kaiser. The company promotes quality services and work life balance. This company stands out for their small caseloads as well as their ongoing trainings and supervision. They are constantly growing and actively promote from within. Easter Seals is a great company for current and future graduate students looking for mentorship and clinical experience.
cons: Over the last several years the Autism service line in Southern California has grown from a handful of employees to the largest in the region.  It has experienced growing pains with policy changes as well as streamlining procedures in order to ensure consistency. Employees who are flexible and work well in group collaborations tend thrive. This may not be the best agency for BCBAs looking for independent field work.

pros: Allowed you to have freedom with activities your group chose and allowed creativity, you got to order your supplies online (90% of the time what you ordered arrived late or not at all due to the person ordering not doing it on time or at all.)
cons:
Incredibly short staffed, management was no help at all, didn't follow through with ANYTHING! If you brought a problem to management they made excuses for it all. 
Hostile work environment due to management and other coworkers. 
There were a few very aggresive clients who hit, choked, kicked, punched, bit, clients and staff, management did nothing about it but made excuses. You feared for your safety around these clients. Management was only worried about the money coming in. Expected you to do the work of 3 people with garbage pay and no raises in sight. 
Management offered no help on the days that were very short staffed. Management locked themselves in the office and wouldn't answer on the walkies or when knocking on the door. 
Management took numerous cigarette breaks throughout the day. 
Very high turn over rate. That comes down to garbage management and pay.

review_title: Easter Seals Midwest:  Anatomy of a Failed Nonprofit
job_title: Community Living Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Camaraderie with coworkers; generous vacation hours; rewarding work with cognitively disabled and autistic individuals.  That's about it.
cons: Unresponsive, sometimes hostile upper management; high turnover; nepotism; low pay; staff are seen as numbers to fill staffing patterns, not people; no raises; retaliation on direct care staff when complaints are made about management; run by incompetents.  This used to actually be 2 failing agencies that merged, and took on the Easter Seals name while still maintaining old policy.  It's kinda like taking a Kmart shirt and sewing a Polo logo on it.  In the end, it's still an inferior product.  Work here if you're a masochist.

review_title: The mission is a good one, but run from this company
job_title: Program Support Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: Nice co-workers, laid-back work environment, camp location grounds are gorgeous. The mission is a good one and the people on the front lines truly care about the work they do.
cons: Work load is absolutely ridiculous. You're expected to do the work of 2-3 people under normal circumstances while having more piled on by office staff daily. Upper management tries to play like everyone is happy and gets along, but the atmosphere is toxic as all get-out. If you aren't willing to put up with being walked all over with a grin plastered across your face, you're labeled as not having "shared purpose." The pay is awful- pretty sure fast food pays better than half the positions here. Oh, and with the Medicaid privatization fiasco they lost all their case managers and a few million off the annual budget. Run from this sinking ship.

review_title: Opportunities for growth, professional and personal.
job_title: Behavior Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: Great opportunity for professional growth. Multidisciplinary team and inspiring mentors. BCBA supervision. Professional and emotional support in dealing with complex cases. Flexibility. Remote indirect work.
cons: Small working space relative to number of employees. Segregation tendencies and same-position clique practices. Employees don't know each other. Isolating at times. Lots of procedural changes, however most of them are welcome since they will benefit not only the clients, but also the staff, and the company in general.

review_title: If PRODUCTIVITY ($$$) is the reason you want to work in the human services field, this is the place for you.
pros: Specific individuals who actually care about their work, helping families, and improving people's lives...however these pros have nothing to do with the actual company, rather specific exemplary human beings who will likely continue their work elsewhere.
cons: No raises, removing benefits one by one from employees, taking away time "allowed" to work on tasks, but expecting the same quality of work from employees, valuing $$$ above everything else, incompetent management that doesn't know its own policies, unprofessionalism abounds, treating employees as expendable bodies, unethical behavior when dealing with employees and clients, dishonesty, complete disconnect between roles, HR, poor scheduling...and on and on and on. It's amazing this company is still operating in its current state.

review_title: great learning experience, no room for growth
pros:
Good learning experience for case management and gaining social service experience. Super great job if you like working with children & families.
The admin tries to do fun things to keep morale high such as parties for holidays and cake once a month for birthdays. The manager was accommodating if one needed to take time away for their child being sick or an illness.
BCBS insurance
cons:
There are about 25 others with your same job position and there is no room for growth and those above are only the manager and assistant program manager, so stuck at the same job with the same salary until you go elsewhere.
There are some unhappy people working there and the management lets them get away with bad attitudes and bad behavior because of their time spent there.
The job involves home visits into many chicago neighborhoods, so it takes a toll on your car, energy, and safety.

pros: Easter Seals Midwest has a good mission and provides a service that is needed in the region. Many families and individuals rely on their work.
cons: All but one person who was on my team has either quit or been let go. The turn over in my former department is very high. The culture of the organization is toxic, meaning groups act as cliques and even bully and victimize staff people. Note at the end of every fiscal year, after the board has set unrealistic fund development goals, a hard working staff person is sacrificed to try to meet budget. Meeting budget is elusive to this organization, as is nurturing respect among the people who serve those in need of services.

pros: Great company.You are given as many hours as you'd like, so I had no problem getting a full-time position. They give you extensive training in ABA, mileage reimbursement, and you get your full hourly pay for drive time. A lot of companies in this field don't do that. This is a perfect place to start in this field because you get hands on experience. There are a lot of opportunities to move up in this field.
cons: Not many. The company as a whole is great. A major con in this field would be that there are always a lot of client cancellations with in-home therapy. Especially during summer.

job_title: Special Education Paraprofessional in Manchester, NH
pros: The kids you work with are tough but sweet and you feel lucky to be there for them. You learn a lot and it's a great way to start your career in SPED or social services. There are some truly dedicated people who work there for the love of the job.
cons: The pay is horrible and the benefits are worse. There are some staff members that work there that take advantage of the clients, are abusive and are not qualified. Also the CEO makes over 500,000 a year but we would have budget cuts that ment residential clients would go without real life skills programs and even winter clothing. There was a saying I found extremely true "it's all about who you know or who you blow"

job_title: Registered Behavior Technician in Peoria, IL
pros:
The families and children you get to work with are amazing! 
They have a lot of highly qualified clinicians
cons:
Easterseals Central IL is the prime example of selling a sugar coated lie to clients. I saw multiple instances where families were told their child was receiving a level of services that were far from the truth

Upper management at the location I worked in was completely clueless to the day to day of providing services, yet sprung huge changes on the clinical staff without any notice 

I was personally a part of initiatives where I and my coworkers were told our duties would be xyz, only to later find our role was nothing like we were told

Pay is terrible compared to other ABA providers, even for a nonprofit

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: It is a great company doing great work for people who cannot help themselves. They provide many opportunities for employees as far as promotions and education. They are also quite involved in the community which is great for the people.
cons: They have a huge employee turn over rate. People were quitting IN training, or with weeks in their position. Communication is very lacking and cause employees to be disgruntled a lot, which makes them unpleasant to work with and puts everyone else in a bad mood as well. They pay is quite low at 11.25/hr and the raises, if you're super lucky, are like 10 cents or less. They do not really fire people because they are so desperate for employees, so there are quite a lot of people that are just basically warm bodies filling a position.

review_title: Poorly paid, poor benefits, top heavy organization
pros: Children who attend are great, co-workers are dedicated to the mission, mission is noble.   Paperwork is not as time- consuming as it is in other  places.
cons: Too many Vice Presidents who are highly paid relative to the rest of the staff.  Mgmt is only concerned with billing and who is a top biller, and therefore, who is paying their bloated salary.  The rest of the staff could have higher salaries, better retirement and more sick/ personal/vacation days at just about any other similar employer in DFW.   Because of this, morale is bad. Mgmt  is only concerned with $, not employee morale.

review_title: A passion for this type of work and little need to make a livable wage is a must.
pros: This Non-Profit is a fairly good place if it's your first job in Human Services. If this type of work is where your heart is, it's very self-rewarding.
cons: Easter Seals pays top to bottom, so those who work on the front lines, (DSAs) who have the most interaction with consumers and face the most challenges in a position that is both physically and mentally exhausting, are very underpaid.  Even working full-time, you can expect your gross income to be well under the poverty line for the state of New Hampshire.  Hard work and dedication often goes unacknowledged.   Staff are often viewed as just "bodies" to fill positions within an organization that has a 68% turnover rate.

pros: This review refers specifically to Easter Seals New Hampshire. Other states operations may be quite different. The only reason to work for ES NH is if you are completely desperate and have no other prospect. The benefit package is decent, everything else is rotten as detailed below.
cons:
Run by a cadre of demented control freaks with a corporate mindset, this organization grinds it's employees  to powder and has minimal to no concern for the people it serves. Any clinical expertise is subordinate to financial concerns, and therapist and line staff are treated like dirt. They adroitly play on people's better nature, and use guilt lavishly to squeeze more work out of people. Consequently, turnover rate is fantastic, especially in rural areas of the state. Downstate they increasingly count on new immigrants who are poorly trained and easier to exploit. 
Steer clear!!

pros: Great staff! You learn a lot and gain lots of experience working with patients with Mental, developmental, and behavioral disabilities!
cons: You really can't work your way up. If you work in a group home and want to work up to be a manager, its tough. They would prefer to bring in someone new, than move up their staff. A lot of decisions are made in management concerning the homes, but its obvious that they don't ask staff their opinion before they make decisions.

pros: Good Employee Relations and Fair Treatment is what this company is all about. From the very first day of my employment with then I felt respected as an employee.
cons: The downsides to working for Easter Seals wouldn't be the company. It would be building a relationship  with the clients of the company , and letting them down by leaving the company. Its so hard for elderly and disabled clients to adjust to having caregivers come in and out of their lives .

pros: Mission and the nature of the work with the clients are great.  Medical benefits through Kaiser were good.
cons:
Hierarchy and disconnect between top management and rest of staff even though the organization was not that big.  Little training and support to staff.  VERY low paying.  Don't factor in raises for inflation, let alone the heavy increases for cost of living in Denver.  Most people had to have a side hustle to make it work.  Technology and systems were a hindrance to doing good work.  High amounts of staff turnover. 
 Would not recommend to work here.

job_title: Service Coordinator in Tinley Park, IL
pros: Although Easter Seals is a non-profit orgainzation, they offer competitive salaries & benefits for their staff. In spite of dificult economic times, ES strives to to show appreciation & gratitude to staff for the work they do.
cons: The contract they have with the state to operate our program, does not appear to take into consideration the growth pattern that has been demonstrated in previous years.  This often leads to being understaffed for the number of families being served.

review_title: The Pros of Cons of working as a therapist at Easter Seals
pros: It has good benefits and schedule flexibility. The management is supportive and down to earth. You have a lot of opportunities to network with people within you field of expertise and with people in related fields. There are plenty of opportunities for continued education.
cons: The pay is not competitive to what some other outpatient facilities may be offering. There are times when there is a lot of turnover of therapists. Since it is non-profit, there is often a limit of compensation that the management can give you.

review_title:
0 stars- unethical company
Easter Seals New Jersey
job_title: Program Coordinator in West Orange, NJ
pros: Helping the consumers. Outside of this they're are no pros in any way shape or form.  There is no silver lining at this jail like job... unless you like using all of your hard earned education on being a puppet...
cons:
Working with upper management is degrading. They're is no sense of team, and only a sense of hierarchy. 
The director of my county unethically refused to interview CMO young adults based on their "assumed" behaviors.  Their only wanted hello and this director held the power to let them fall through the cracks.  
HR is there to help management legally terminate staff- I have sat in meetings where this was suggested to me by HR and my director.

pros: Working with the client population is such a gift. They are special people who will be tough to help at times, but ultimately will teach you as much as you teach them.
cons: The management at Easter Seals in Norwich is very cutthroat. There are many managers and supervisors but they tend to give varying instructions and there appears to be a lot of infighting among them. They do not address staff issues as they come up, but instead leave it to the staff to sort out, which frequently leaves an atmosphere of hostility and mistrust.

pros: The kids!!!   The kids is the reason why you take a job like that, some just tug at your heart.  You could be having the worse day ever, and you will have that one child that is totally non verbal come up to you with a smile and give you a little side hug.  It is all about the kids, they are amazing.
cons: Horrible pay!! There is a lack of leadership from the CEO down. You are just a number to them.  There is a huge amount of bulling that goes on between staff. At times it had a high school mentality. The staff that cares is over worked and the rest don't care. By the time I left all of my fellow associates that I trained with  had already left or were going to. They need to get there act together for the kids,  those children deserve better and a staff that wants to stay.

pros: This was more than a training program, although you learned a lot, but the hands on is the best training one can receive, you learned all procedures of how an office is suppose to operate on a daily basis
cons:
The only thing I can think of is everybody at Easter Seals is working on 
a contract, and you would hope that they would hire you, so after my first 4 years I was asked to renew my contract for another 4 years, and I was hoping that they would hire me. I was told no money in budget, this was a government sponsored program.

review_title: Easter Seals Bay Area does not provide ABA
pros: My colleagues and families were the best part of this organization.  My immediate supervisors were very supportive.  Co-workers at a similar level (e.g. Clinical Managers and Behavior Interventionists) were very collaborative.
cons: Corporate is corrupt, shows favoritism and does not value their employees.  Behavior Interventionists are viewed as "cash cows" and are not respected for the incredibly important and challenging work they do.  The actual program is not ABA and there's little emphasis on providing evidence-based services.  Just because someone holds a license does not qualify them to develop and provide ABA services.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Raleigh, NC
pros: Having worked some places with horrible network reliability. Easter Seals NCVA has a pretty stable network that allows ease of remote support. The small size of the corporate office allows you to get to know your co workers and they are generally good people who care about what they do.
cons: Little room to move up, no raises, and management doesn't really connect well with the lower tier workers. For the lack of benefits there needs to be some kind of incentive given to keep good employees.

pros: IF the CEO in Austin likes you, he will say hi to you, perhaps even a couple of words.  If you are female, he likes to flirt.  If you are into being treated like raw meat, this is the place for you.
cons: The work environment does not encourage or even want constructive feedback. the CEO makes over $200k per year, rarely is seen in the office, and did not know the name of the grants funding his programs. There is a lot of talent, but they would rather reinvent the wheel or hire outside consultants than listen to staff. The organization has about a two week operating contingency and year over year finances decline an average of 40%. You'll never hear about ESCT being in the forefront of the Austin non-profit scene. Very disappointing.

pros: It is like working with a family here, the people are more than just your coworkers. Every day is different and has it's own set of challenges, but it's a very relaxed work environment.
cons: If you are looking to move up the ladder, it is hard here. Your role might change even through your job title stays the same, so if you can't swing gears at the drop of a hat, this isn't the place for you. You are likely to have lateral job transfers but to move up to management is hard and non existent.

review_title: Just go teach, this isn't worth it

cons: No growth no paid summers not even unemployment terrible management  85% of family's we serve in Atlanta do not use the program to better them self only for baby sitting purpose I have been with the company for 5 yrs and only see the same family's in heave rotation our CEO Donna use special needs and minority to get grants but do not allocate the money the right way. stop reading things on paper and come check Easter seals of north Georgia out.

review_title: company is doing great work, pay doesn't commensurate

pros: i worked on the corporate side in the main office. flexibility in scheduling. lots of PTO. very affordable health benefits. small team, great spirit.

review_title: Feedback is always average or needs improvement.  Not much positive reinforcement.  They don't lead by example.

cons: People made managers and supervisors without the social skills, education or training to lead others.  Leave your self centeredness aside and focus on helping the clients.  Otherwise, go to school.

review_title: Not a sustainable way of life
pros:
Seemingly making a change in a child's life. 
Great Coworkers and office atmosphere (when you get to go to the office).
cons:
This type of job is not a sustainable way to live. You are enticed to the position with a good per hour salary and hopes of becoming full-time but it never happens and if it does it is never for long. 

At any moment your case load can drop for any reason and you will just be out of luck and expected to be on-call all day waiting to fill in for other Interventionists as a substitute which most people hate to do. You literally get a call and have to go to someone's home that you have never been to and see a child who is most likely triggered by changes to a daily routine and wing-it. These children do not like substitutes most of the time which makes it more likely for you to get hit or look like a fool for 2, 3, or even 4 hours as they cower in the corner trying to get away from you. Parents usually dislike this too and are quick to let you know. You are expected to do this at the drop of a dime to earn money or you don't get paid. Not to mention sometimes these kids are over an hour away. Even when it is not in the best interest of the child to see a substitute you are expected to do it because it brings in money and they can bill for it. Excuses are made such as it is great for generalizing when in reality half the time you are entertainment, a babysitter or the kid's worst nightmare when you substitute.

Behavior Interventionists get the short end of every stick and do the most work. They do the most driving per day (sometimes over 100 miles), they see the clients and parents the most, enter all the data, take all the data, make the materials and are expected to live up to insane standards under crazy situations. Sad to say it but a lot of the times the children hit, curse, want you to leave and parents talk to you like absolute trash all day. When you report it back nothing is done. Parents can continue the next day as you sit in their house being hit by their child. 

It seems to come down to BI's being the breadwinners for the company. BI's are expected to earn all the money by seeing the clients and everyone else gets the pay from it. There are so many unnecessary jobs in administration or higher that get paid way too much money and never even see a kid in person. The top gets paid the most and it dwindles down to the BI's who basically get the scraps but are made to believe that they only deserve 18 bucks an hour for seeing the client when the actual sessions are being billed for hundreds. 

If you want a job where you will drive tirelessly all day (wasting lots of gas), have no guaranteed hours (regardless of what they promise you), get physically and verbally abused all day (while being absolutely selfless), lots of work and little reward, be emotionally and financially drained and get little to no benefits this is the job for you. 
Does that sound like a job you would like?

review_title: direct support associate  for Easter Seals of New Hampshire

review_title: Invaluable Life Lessons, Would Not Pursue Career in Non-Profit Due to Experience Here
pros:
Exposed to various disabilities in the job and had the opportunity to empower others
Some of the clients I had taught me invaluable life lessons, and I will forever hold those individuals dear
cons:
The pay was so low that I could hardly afford gas and food.  A colleague who was hired after me (and had no college degree or relevant experience) was offered almost $10,000 more - and not because she negotiated.
There was a kind of "fraternity/sorority" feel to the Indianapolis location while I worked there.  My team manager would pitch girls against each other through gossip and back-stabbing.  I was also expected to use my own vehicle to take clients to interviews all over town with no mileage reimbursement, and much damage to my vehicle even within a few months' time.  We never signed any kind of liability form, so I would not have been protected if there had been an accident or lawsuit at any point.
Unfortunately, if you were low on the totem pole you were treated as dispensable, which resulted in high turnover.  My experience here turned me away from pursuing work in the non-profit sector. I will gladly volunteer, but the bald corruptness in treatment, salaries, and unreasonable time expectations were unable to balance out the wonderful time I had with those whom I served.

pros: A great place to work.  Before I worked there, I was an individual receiving services.  They sent a worker out to my job to help me.  When I got laid off there, they gave me a job.  But apparently they expected me to stay forever.  When they found out I had another job, they threatened to replace me.  I finally resigned on December 28th, 2012.
cons: Supervisors were very vindictive.  If they felt you "owed them a favor", they meant it.

review_title: Poorly managed, not mission-focused, workers expendable
pros: I enjoyed my time working for the national office in some regards. In the beginning I felt like I was making a difference and that the organization was working to get back on track following multiple rounds of lay-offs, even while they paid a senior leader $780K a year and executive team members $400K or more. I did sometimes feel like my work was making a difference but had to really look for how my efforts would trickle down to the local level.
cons:
I don’t know how else to say it but very little of dollars raised goes to help people with disabilities. You are FAR better off giving to your local Easter Seals affiliate than the national office. While I was there years ago and a hurricane happened down South, the company texted supporters asking for $19-$100 donations. I watched first hand as those funds came in and the. entered a general operating fund and never once were directed to the affiliate in that area. 

Work life balance was crappy, too.  Some staff received schedule modifications (like being off Fridays) if they were buddy-buddy with management, not based on tenure or work performance.  HR actually stunk at actually being neutral, and frequently gossiped across the office about staff and their performance. I had a few things I wanted to address during my tenure but never felt comfortable doing so because of this lack of confidentiality and neutrality.

There was a four year freeze in staff raises during which the CEO hemorrhaged money and continued to collect a $750K annual paycheck. I was given an enormous amount of grief anytime I used sick leave, despite never once using all my time earned or going into the negative. What are benefits for if not to be used when you need them?
