cons:
Work/Life balance talked about, but not really supported enforced
Management is NOT transparent
Administrative policies/procedures are too focused on parenting rather than accountability
Too many great people in the wrong positions and vis versa

pros: I learned a great deal about planning processes while working for Easter Seals. Unfortunately, very few departments stuck to their plans, nor did leadership encourage them to do so. Instead, departments bounced from one idea to another, getting very little accomplished.
cons: Competition, not cooperation, was encouraged between departments and even staff. The "Blame Game" is played at a very high level. The organization lags behind in the disability rights movement, sometimes saying it doesn't exists.

job_title: Site Manager/Service Coach in Flemington, NJ
pros: Work with other people who are like minded. Flexibility with schedule and to travel to different areas daily. Seeing growth in the consumers you work with.
cons: The pay was horrible for the amount of work you do. Barely get recognition for good service. No appreciation from the organization as a whole.

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Training team was patient and helpful.
cons: During the interview, I was told the core hours were from 1p-7p and that I must be available to work a minimum of 10 hours per week. On the last day of the two week training, I received an email from HR stating that my available hours (which were over 25 per week) were not going to work with scheduling. The HR rep mentioned a totally different time frame that I needed to be available to work.

pros:
Great people to work with 
Worthy mission
cons:
"Parent" organization loosing sight of who it serves (itself or people with disabilities) 
Lack of transparency 
Poor communication and organization

pros: My coworkers were nice, the benefits and 401k match were great, and the team was generally supportive to get things done.
cons: The management was pretty incompetent, and it was clear that those in leadership roles only held such positions because they knew someone or had gotten in with the right people.

pros: Love the kids and families. Great opportunity to help a population of people in need.
cons: No control over your schedule and the schedulers are "mean girls". They take care of a few that they like and if you are not on their cool list you suffer. If they don't give you hours, you don't make money. Company makes up titles and promotes based on friendships. Very top heavy. They don't take care of the people on the bottom. The ones that bring in the money for the program.

review_title: Great place to gain experience in the mental health and special needs field
pros: You can gain a great deal of initial experience in the mental health field and you have opportunities to move around within the company. There are people who care about you.
cons: Only major con is that there are not many incentives for employees and keeping a balance between work and your life can be difficult at times.

job_title: Lead Teacher in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Helpful to their clients and offer many services to the public. Offer ways to give back to the community by volunteering at one of their many events. Free circus tickets for employees.
cons: Not helpful to employees, incentives are non-existent. Any suggestions are met with laughter from H.R. Women are forced on maternity leave or made to quit. Pay is not fair and set low for what parents pay for tuition

pros: Working at Easterseals as a caregiver gives you the comfort of working in a home and removes the stress of constant orders and micromanaging. Your weekly schedule is provided and so is the client's weekly itinerary so you have your work cut out for you. Laid-back work environment (depending on the house and supporting staff).
cons: Managers aren't always available to answer your calls or troubleshoot problems as they arise. Weekend managers are sometimes unresponsive and unavailable to cover for staff during emergencies, despite claiming that that's what they're there for.

review_title: Could be great... but is not
pros: Flexible schedule, great kiddos and free training
cons: Poor communication, senior management fraternizing with subordinate staff of opposite sex, favoritism, inconsistent scheduling, lack of training, facility run down, poor leadership, no benefits

review_title: Professional acumen of mid to senior level management is staggeringly low.
pros: A great mission, with broad reach across a large number of populations in need of services.
cons: There is a significant disconnect between senior management and what is actually occurring in the workplace. Easter Seals NH is mostly concerned with revenue, and the financial condition of the operation is poor. There is little awareness of how to connect management processes to performance, and behaviors permitted in a workplace that is rife with nepotism are atrocious.

pros: Families you serve and very grateful of the services you provide making the experience very rewarding.  You truly make a significant different in the client's life as well as their families.
cons: Supervisors vary depending on the case, some show more commitment than others.  Hours are not very flexible.  Cancellations result in no pay, very unstable job as a behavioral interventionist.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Lake Tahoe, CA
pros: Excellent management,  complete and thorough training for required job responsibilities.  Good, informative evaluation process upon completion of seasonal position.
cons:
If you are unable to work hard, work long hours or unable to  commit to the position. you would not be suited for the work.  
Really no opportunities to transfer your experience or work skills to other positions at Easter Seals.n

review_title: One of the better ABA companies
pros: Staff is dedicated to making a difference and giving quality services to clients, lower billable in comparison to the industry standard, company is non profit which means they don't force employees to bill an a high amont of hours to generate revenue.
cons: This agency shares the same cons as others in this field. Work life balance is off when you work in this field.

job_title: Special Education Paraprofessional in Chicago, IL
pros: I had the privilege of working alongside interesting and dedicated coworkers.
cons: The working environment was racist, sexist, and fear-based (there are security cameras in every classroom and hallway). The "education" was so bad that there wasn't even enough funding for worksheets...teachers printed out a dozen worksheets, laminated them, and had students fill out the same sheets over and over again, day after day, with erasable whiteboard markers. Also, very low pay...the majority of FULL TIME staff had second jobs, and many even qualified for food stamps.

pros: Clinical staff is excellent, supportive and intelligent. Medical benefits are good.
cons: Upper management have no contact with employees in branch offices and create cruel anti-labor policy, that hurts lower level, hard working, passionate employees. My pay has steadily decreased over my years of employment at this agency, and has caused my quality of life to go down.

review_title: Highly unorganized.  Going through a growth spurt at the time of my hire.
job_title: Autism Behavior Interventionist in Oakland, CA
pros: Very kind co-workers. Interventionists, most supervisors and managers were friendly and approachable.
cons: Upper management did not keep promises regarding territory I would be working in.  Low-balled regarding salary upon hire.  Limited training--2 weeks less than what was promised upon hire.  Lack of quality on-going training.  Repetitive trainings that covered the same scenarios.

review_title: Better than the alternatives for entry-level behavior therapists
job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: steady hours (even when parents cancel, which happens a lot), supportive work environment, decent mileage reimbursement, never work early mornings, fairly straightforward/ easy to understand data sheets, generous vacation time and sick days
cons: tons of driving, rarely see co-workers (can feel isolating), disorganized due to rapid growth (likely a temporary problem), staff supervising behavioral interventionists are not typically BCBA certified (in the bay area at least), can't move up in the company without a masters

job_title: Direct Support Professional in East Brunswick, NJ
pros: Getting to work with and help great people. Flexible schedule and enjoy the companionship with the clients.
cons: Since this is a non-profit organization the pay tends to be low. If you are looking to make a lot of money, this is not the job for you, but If you are looking for a rewarding career helping others, this is an excellent start.

review_title: To many clients for the amount of pay
pros: My first boss was awesome as well as the QM. Human Resources rocks!
cons: To many hats for the amount of pay. You had to manage 12 clients spread over 2 locations.  Your input as far as residents in the group home goes to deaf doors. All they want are to fill the beds at the cost of injury to current residents.

review_title: This agency has very poor leadership, no opportunity for advancement, financial instability and very low employee morale
job_title: Payroll Specialist in Santa Fe, NM
pros: Opportunity to serve the developmentally disabled and the elderly.
cons: Upper management does not communicate downward to mid and lower level employees, either about direction, motivation and new developments.  Management style is very old school, using tyranny and bullying rather than team spirit and motivation.  Many employees are constantly in fear of losing their jobs due to the financial instability of the agency.

job_title: Coordinator/Community Living Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Interaction with the clients.  A sense of accomplishment when they learn new skills.
cons: Supervisors are not always professional.  Low pay.  In some of the houses clients are aggressive.  No one thinks of asking the advice of the workers who deal directly with the clients when changes are made.

review_title: Poor management sinks this otherwise great employer
pros: The mission at Easter Seals in the DC|MD|VA region is second to none and they have very generous benefits even for new employees.
cons: The senior staff is controlling and micro-manages every project, no matter how large or small.  There is no room for creativity, positive feedback is non-existent.  There is no opportunity for growth and the Senior Management team is demanding, ignores personal boundaries and is dictatorial in their style.

pros: You get plenty of experience working with families and great people. Your supervisors do a good job of backing you up and making you feel secure in your position.
cons: Benefits only for full time staff, there is no gas reimbursement for driving the client to other locations. I cared for siblings and was still only paid $8/hr. I was not given more for caring for multiple people even if I didn't have coworkers helping me and I was usually caring for 2+ special needs children

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bragg Creek, AB
pros:
Very flexible work hours during school year.
31 days paid vacation.
Great team dynamic amongst camp staff.
Casual work environment.
Good balance between independent/team work settings and tasks.
On site living included in compensation package - love the lifestyle!
The work is incredibly rewarding.
cons:
Running summer camps is all consuming - as with any camp.
City offices can have a hard time understanding the unique challenges of a camp environment.
Majority of Sr. Management is on the older side (near retirement)

job_title: ABA Therapist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Easterseals ensures that they provide services to the best of their abilities while remaining within appropriate ethical boundaries. This company is a family and a community that is full of employees encouraging, assisting, and motivating each other to provide the best possible care to the individuals that Easterseals serves.
cons: Pay for this position is not competitive, but recently they have been making changes to ensure that employees are paid based on experience and evaluations, not just equal for all employees at this level.

pros: They tell you how much you’re appreciated. When you do the right thing, they look out for you. Closed weekends and most holidays.
cons:
There is somewhat of a high turnover rate. It could be because of the pay. Everyone isn’t meant to work in childcare. 
Unfortunately, sometimes, you get stuck working with someone who hates their job. That make things worse than what it should be. 

Insurance rates aren’t the best—especially with how little we’re paid.

review_title: There has to be something better.
pros: Work from home employment. Working with kiddos. HR department.
cons: Multiple changes. The game telephone is played with the delivery of critical clinical information. If you are interested in training it  is impossible to penetrate the training team unless you have a solid relationship with the training director.

pros: Given a lot of autonomy and responsibility. A great place to learn the industry and grow skils in non-profit management and direct care.
cons: Because the admin rate is so low, they do not invest in personnel. The turnover rate is outrageous, and a lot of time is spent training new hires who are almost always entry level.

job_title: Community Service Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Decent amount of vacation time allowed
cons: Management not concerned about low morale. No pay raises have been given for years. Many supervisors have poor social skills and treat employees in a degrading manner. Initial training is poor and new employees are often placed in situations that overwhelm them. Insurance is expensive and co-pays are too high. The agency is more concerned with generating revenue than with providing quality service. They hire basically anyone and many employees are not trustworthy.

pros: Great job for students since hours of operation are typically 3-7 pm. Hours are not long.
cons: It is difficult to get full time employment unless you are willing to work weekends, although that still may not give you enough hours to reach full-time. The services are also provided in home which can cause awkward or uncomfortable situations due to differing moral values.

pros: Loved the work and mission, they step in when no one else will, do great work, and improve lives.
cons:
Employees are overworked and the organization lacks capacity-- I was investigated by the DOL while working here.
Required to double workload without a promotion or a raise.
Senior staff focused on weaknesses and challenges rather than strengths and rarely showed gratitude.
High turnover due to a negative work environment and lack of support.

review_title: contracted to provide disability services for the state
pros: Had acceptable benefits and salary.
cons: Because I worked for a sub-contracted agency, I don't know who to blame for the emphasis change from helping people (I taught Spanish speakers English, so they could find work), to simply caring about the numbers.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in Moreno, Riverside, CA
pros: Rewarding work, convenient hours for those working and going to school simultaneously, same pay for administrative tasks done at home, offer 20% off a masters at national university and educational reimbursement pay
cons: High energy job, BIs tend to be disregarded, parents are usually great but because ESSC requires a co-pay for each session they have high expectations

job_title: Aquatic Rehabilitation Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros: The leadership is spearheaded by determined and dedicated individuals, driven to make a reality the company  mission statement. All employees possess a kindness and caring for others unparalleled.
cons: The financial compensation is limited and financial growth is frozen. The compensation for my former position is minimum wage. Hours for my former position are also scarce.

review_title: Great people, not many opportunities for growth
pros: Really motivated and and passionate people, doing great work to assist children and their families, very rewarding work
cons: Pretty much no opportunities for growth without committing to grad school, hours are unstable, minimal to no interacting with coworkers on a purely social level (only through team meetings)

pros:
-Very extensive training period. 
-excellent support from PMs 
-rewarding job 
-one of the highest paying companies that offer ABA
cons:
-very hard to get full-time hours. 
-Unpredictable schedule. A lot of clients cancel last minute. 
-In order for you to get more hours you have to have an open schedule and be willing to work 6 days a week.

pros: Great way to have face-to-face interactions with people with disabilities.
cons: Working conditions are intense (long hours, low pay, up to 12 days straight w/o day off) so most camp staff come from UK/abroad. Camp supervisor extremely unprofessional and fired live-in,  on-site nurse without any prior notice (basically called a taxi and told her she had to leave the premises immediately).

pros: Good benefits and paid-time off.
cons: Extremely high productivity rate and when not achieved that 85% productivity rate, supervisors scold you. When you do achieve it, you are not appreciated for your hard work. 3 initial evaluations are done in one day followed by an IFSP. Most of the time you don't eat lunch because you're rushed from home-to home.  You bring a lot of work home due to the inability to write up evaluation reports and IFSP's in home setting.  The paperwork/caseload ratio does not match. Supervisors expect unrealistic goals from therapists.  You work extremely hard and the compensation does not match.  The turnover rate is extremely fast.

pros: Goals are set and are gone about seriously. Profit is made obviously as bonuses are given to staff every now and then
cons: There is complacency in the attitude of the staff towards the growth and can be redressed by making the staff familiar with the organization goals

job_title: Behavior Therapist in San Jose, CA
pros: Get to see the kids show progress, PTO, benefits, paid mileage and drive time
cons: No backups or flexibility when you have a last minute cancellation, the distance between clients can be unfair, supervisors can change your mileage and time (have to tell you)

pros: I like to work with numbers. I am using my accounting  and math skills.  I am a independant worker and at the same time work as a team, also. I have some flexibility about hours.
cons: If employees are not sending the time-sheet at the right time or not clear about their working hours and dates. Make sure document correctly for overpayment or underpayment or any changes we made.

review_title: Great Place to Work - If you are motivated
pros:
- you get to help people
- co-workers and direct managers are good people who care
- decent pay 
- committed to professional development of employees
- open to ideas and trying new approaches
cons:
-benefits are terrible, health plan is too expensive
-lately there is a lot of turn over in management
- so departments are disorganized

pros: Can have a flexible schedule, you first hand get to see the positive transformation in your work, you work with a diverse group of children
cons:
very low pay and no room for growth within company without furthering your education. not enough communication with managers, supervisors and other bis.
you have to drive sometimes long distances from one client to another. 
some of the homes are really dirty and parents sometimes treat you like babysitters

pros: Comradeship, clients and management. Great team environment. A lot of fun and laughs are in abundance. Very laid back atmosphere.
cons: Pay, hours, collaterals. They company is willing to pay well but you must fight for it and have no claims against you which is virtually impossible.

pros: Helping Special Needs individuals, and making a difference in lives, is what it is all about. Seeing the difference in children after therapies are applied are worth more than all of the money in the world!!!
cons: There is only so much change that you can effect. I wish we could make more of a difference than we are already making. that's why we need more passionate indidviduals to enter this field!!!!

job_title: Workforce Development Specialist in Waukesha, WI
pros: None, I pull my hair out and scream in frustration daily.  My office alone has seen a 65 percent turn over in just the last year alone.
cons: Very low pay, verbal harassment from upper management, When harassment was brought to HR they said that it would not make a difference because of the importance of the upper manager the issue would more than likely be dropped.  HR also plays favorites when it comes to transfers and will regularly pass up highly qualified individuals for friends with little to no experience.

review_title: Staff is what made the company!!
pros: Started as a intern and from their worked part time and full time.. The employees is what made the company wonderful and the great clients...
cons: The major cutbacks within Easterseals nationwide..  I had a bachelors started making 10 dollars with some clients and 11 dollars with others.. They cut mileage, and a lot of budget cuts within the company..It was not a place for growth.. Because of the budget cuts..

pros: teamwork, supportive coworkers,good pay,team meeting every day in am,- to keep up with client`s conditions, and know where each team member will be, and what they will be doing
cons: emotionally, and mentally stressful, too many changes, lot of paperwork, too many continuing ed. requirements

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros:
Room to advance 
Invested in higher education of the employees
Care about their staff
Expanding rapidly
cons: As the company expands quickly, it is hard to keep up with staffing

pros: Nice place to work but the hours are a little slow. However  they offer training on site and also online. Some supervisors work well with you but others do not.  Great place to work with for the children and parents.
cons: Need to offer benefits for part-time, most supervisors do not work with you. Low pay and no raises. No growth within the company.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Fort Wayne, IN
pros:
None. Worst place ever.
Loved my clients though. Very challenging work but very rewarding career. Just not here.
cons: Worst place to work. No on the job training at all. Pay is laughable for the amount of work. Management basically throws you to the wolves if you need help with anything.  Was hired for a "permanent position" during an influx of clients and let go for no reason when the clients realized how much this place sucks and left also.

review_title: Overall it was a good experience for a company who just began to service the Autistic community.
job_title: Behavior Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Ran very corporately! Paid holidays for all full-time employees. Fair cancellation policy. Education reimbursement available. Trainings were paid at your full rate. Lots of trainings.
cons: Not enough BCBA to provide supervision hours for those employees seeking to sit for the BACB examination. There are very few cons to ESSC!

review_title: College Friendly, but not a lifelong job to have
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Allentown, PA
pros: Fairly decent pay for a college student, flexible with hours ( primarily 9 to 2 for part timers or 2 to 5 depending on consumer needs), no weekends, no holidays (including Black Friday), and dependable coworkers
cons: Use your own vehicle, no company vehicles are available. Yes, you do get mileage reimbursement but you really rack miles on your own vehicle, and upper management is not always helpful.

review_title: Top heavy organization with management not having clients or staff's best interests in mind
pros: I supervised excellent people and got to do truly meaningful work to assist individuals with disabilities to improve their lives
cons: Executive management was extremely close minded, picked favorites, ignored the suggestions of staff who had experience based on working with the clients, promoted and hired unfairly, made poor financial decisions not in the best interest of the clients, the staff, or the mission of the organization, and deliberately kept staff out of contact with the Board of Directors to limit accountability.

pros: The work done at ESC is so rewarding! The organization has a great mission and upholds great values. There is always opportunity to learn with this organization. Benefits are decent. This job has provided great experience that has helped me in new employment opportunities.
cons: Wages and salaries are not fair or competitive. Corporate employees are making an unfair amount of money compared to the direct consumer care employees.

review_title: This is a very difficult place. Low pay. Poor working conditions.
pros: If you are good with people that need help, and you are kind and patient, you can accomplish a lot with your life.
cons: Lack of communication between the layers of staff can really foul things up and create dangerous situations

pros: Easter Seals Washington is clear in their mission to serve individuals with disabilities. Although they have programs spread across the state of Washington, you have opportunities to meet and collaborate with your colleagues across the state and receive great support from the Seattle office whenever you need it.
cons: Like many nonprofit organizations, there are never quite enough dollars or enough people to do all of the work that you would like to do.

pros: Working for Easter Seals makes you just feel good inside. No matter what your job is you are doing something everyday that makes a difference in the lives of others.
cons: Working for a non for profit company has it's drawbacks. Make sure your salary is one you are happy with when you start because it's not likely to change. Ever.

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in San Diego, CA
pros: Easter seals seems to have a positive workplace culture. I did not feel pressured or overworked.
cons: Not much of an annual raise. I work in autism services and they changed the pay for drive time multiple times to where I was being paid less than when I started.

job_title: Master's Level QP in Rocky Mount, NC
pros: Working on the ACTT team was an amazing experience. We felt more like a family than a team we supported one another professionally and personally and kept the company moral high so we could provide quality services for our clients.
cons: It was an emotionally taxing job due to the population of people that we served, however we were encouraged to take personal days to avoid burnout.

pros: Rewarding! The people we serve, our volunteers, our donors and our staff are fun people. There is an expectation to go the extra mile for our consumers. The accomplishment of a job well done is also rewarding!
cons: It is a non-profit, we operate on a limited budget and our technology is from the 1990's

job_title: Family Outreach Worker in Manchester, NH
pros: Great opportunity to work with youth living with trauma.   Coworkers are pleasant and generally care for each other.  Management is supportive and generally listen to concerns of employees and youth.
cons: Unrealistic expectations for completing necessary agency documents, while ensuring the best care for clients.  Like most agencies understaffed and enadequate training.  Little room for growth.

review_title: Great Company, harder to get hours in small towns
pros:
Flexible schedules
Great management
Genuine care for clients and staff
cons:
You can only get so many hours per client (understandably) so it's harder to get full time hours in small towns.
Sometimes a client will have a large number of hours available per week which is good that they have the option but actually using that many hours for say, a young child, can be hard on them.

pros: I got great janitorial experience!
cons: The program was not what they made it out to be. You're working with severely mentally ill patients who are supposed to be getting help establishing a routine and learning to take care of themselves to become more independent. Management does not know how to motivate the consumers to do anything for themselves and does not follow through with the rules in place so staff becomes nothing more than janitorial staff that caters to the consumers every need. The program is not helping the consumers, it is making them more dependent.

pros: Easter Seals has great intentions and really try to look out for each client and their services.  As an employee, you are able to reach out and connect to great special needs adults.  Flexible hours.
cons: Lack of supervision.  Disorganized.  Unable to receive extra money working over-time since pay roll department could not support it.

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: some employees are there for the right reason and have a good heart
cons: was lied to when hired, told I would get reimbursement for toys and didn't, expected to buy bags full of toys out of pocket, some supervisors are hired without any past ABA experience and were not able to be helpful, they would stop services with families without consulting them or ensuring the families are prepared for the transition, a lot of people there are fake and unsupportive

pros: The mission of this organization is wonderful and they help a lot of people in need.
cons: Easter Seals UCP is in serious financial trouble. Years of mismanagement and poor leadership are to blame. Invoices don't get paid on time, the retirement plan is frozen, morale is awful & no raises for years! I would not recommend working here.

pros: Such a welcoming environment for little ones to grow and learn. The other teachers were well trained and I felt confident when teaching with them
cons: The salary was very low for how hard we worked. It is a non-profit company, so I do understand that does effect the pay scale, however, I worked long hours as a salaried employee and never saw any over time pay for it.

pros: understanding environment and a great work culture. Great benefits and there was room for advancement.
cons: Salary is a bit low, however for the market it is in the upper tier. Strong productivity standards were expected and sometimes in order to hit these numbers individuals that we served were double and triple booked. This at times would cause people to loose sight of serving the individuals and instead worrying about numbers.

pros: It is 8-5.  Nice office. Some people are friendly.
cons: the pay, PTO has to be used for everything, no adjustments of coming in early and getting off early, or not taking a lunch to make up for time. Very strict on PTO. Not flexible with things you need to do if you dont have PTO you short.  There is no matching 403B and the benefits arent that great.

job_title: Lead Scheduler in Los Angeles, CA
pros: lots of OT, consistent work, helping children receive treatment
cons: so much work, never enough time. The higher level executives have no idea how much work the position entails. Tend to praise the clinical team and forget about the administrative staff that tie all the logistics together

review_title: Good place to work but too much turn-over
pros: Fun and overall supportive staff who are very good ABA practitioners. The system they use, the early start Denver model, is a very strong modality.
cons: The work, while incredibly rewarding was repetitive and quite emotionally draining. I saw a lot of challenging family situations; be ready for intensity!

review_title: A great organization to work for
pros: Despite this organizations larger size, each program is small, giving the atmosphere a close-knit feeling. There is a sincere concern for consumers and most employees are dedicated and professional. Management is mostly fair and supportive.
cons: They're not too many opportunities for advancement because each program and small.

pros: The people here have helped my family not end up homeless, they have helped us pay our rent through outside charities. Everyone here has been helpful and kind.
cons: If anything, I wish I could actually get more hours, or an actual job.Otherwise it has been a very good experience.

pros: opportunity for growth and promotions. However you to work many hours and you at a set salary.
cons: At times the work environment can become hostile, in addition to confidential medical or personal information being leaked from HR.

pros: The only pro is seeing progress made in the children!
cons:
- Does not follow-through with promises made during interview/hiring process.
- Very un-supportive supervision staff.
- Gives very low hours, frequent cancellation of hours, and does not make-up hours for cancellations made by children/their families. Very impractical and unstable for maintaining a cost of living.
- Families seems to all be unhappy with the programs and service they receive.

pros: I enjoyed some of my coworkers.
cons: Complete lack of support for employees. Employees are extremely micro-managed but when an employee needs something the management is totally hands-off. Management is extremely disconnected from employees. Poor benefits, low salary, excessive demands of your time (forget work life balance, it's not an option), poor organization and communication. Excessive turnover and very low morale.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good mission and wonderful clients. Lower level staff are all well meaning and the clientele is wonderful.  Lots of learning opportunities too!
cons: Terrible, heartless management that left many families in the lurch and took advantage of staff.  Low pay and limited opportunities for career development without further study.

review_title: This company does great things for the consumers they serve, but employee morale is terrible.
pros: Appears to have quite a bit of promotion from within. The company provides great services to the community
cons: Very little positive feedback, animosity between departments, no opportunities for salary increase, very high turnover, very low level of employee morale, very little communication between departments/a lot of cloak and dagger-like communication. Overworked employees with very little compensation.

review_title: Decent place to work for the short-term
job_title: Direct Care Professional in Des Moines, IA
pros: Rewarding job most of the time. Had a recognition program in place for employees. Had the option of working 4 10-hour days with 3 days off a week. Had a lot of independence in my job.
cons: Lots of driving for my position. Some clients are very difficult to work with. In addition some clients themselves or their homes were very unhygienic and/or reeked of smoke.

pros: Great mission. They really care about serving people and giving them the best treatment possible so that they can live independently.
cons: The process can be confusing. A lot of that is HIPAA but some of it is the company's policies. Still a good company though.

pros: Awesome experience working with co worker and members. Which makes a productive environment. The co workers are great and very helpful.
cons: Management has NO clue as to what they doing. They scape goat and have poor leadership capabilities. Know one seems to know anything. They don't follow policy and procedures.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Suisun City, CA
pros: Great place to get experience. Working with children with Autism is rewarding and staff and others BI's are great to work with.
cons: Pay should be higher to compensate for the behavioral issues we deal with.  There are a lot of cancellations with no compensation.  Sometimes there are sub sessions, but not always with last minute cancellations.

review_title: Company is fine, but there are always issues with middle management.
pros: Employee benefits are not bad - paid time off can make up for sub-par compensation

review_title: Do Not Work Here- Easter Seals SC
pros: Wonderful families and children. I absolutely loved weekly visits with families and supporting them based on their specific needs. The job itself is great- its management and work load that ruins the beauty of the job and your purpose. Choose a different EI company to work for- you'll be so much happier!
cons: Management in South Carolina branch is horrible. The director is power hungry, and they care nothing more than about the billing and money coming in (not about the children). It is completely normal at Easter Seals to have 20-24 children that you're seeing weekly, when a normal caseload is 12-17 kids. Not to mention, they spread you out into 3-4 counties, so you're spending so much time driving when you need to have office time to keep up with all the paperwork. (Most) supervisors and all of management do not have a grip on what the work load is like, or either they just don't care. I've never heard of so many unhappy families because they've had multiple EIs.  This is due to EIs quitting within a month or two because of the work load. Its sad because the children get attached to the EIs, and then they have to meet a new EI, and the pattern continues on and on. I know many families who have switched companies because of this problem. Easter Seals has a terrible reputation in SC, but management won't take the time to implement new ideas to help keep their employees.

review_title: Worst Organization Ever-Do Not Work for Easter Steals
pros: There wasn't a single good thing about this organization.
cons: This is a horrible, miserly, poorly managed organization.  The pay is extremely low, the benefits are worthless.  The only thing Easter Steals is interested in is to persuade naive donors to donate money to the organization so that they can reward the executive team with unrealistic salaries and huge bonuses.  As for the real workers, the turnover rate is above 50% per year. That alone should tell you everything you need to know about this organization.  They do not care about their employees and they can not keep talent.  They only care about sucking in more money from the unknowing donors.  What a horrible, wretched, filthy office to run their scam operation out of.  The employee moral is in the gutter and management is clueless about how to engage employees in their work. Easter Steals is without doubt the worst place I've ever worked and I am glad to be out of that horrible place.  Advice to anyone.  Don't contribute a single cent to this scam outfit.  Don't apply for a job at this place.  You'll be disappointed.  The pay is in the gutter and there are no promotional opportunities. The benefits are horrible and they get skimpier every year.  Essentially Easter Steals has no benefits on top of being extremely low pay.  Hold out until you can find another job, because if you work for Easter Steals, you will regret your decision from the first day and from your first incredibly small paycheck.  Never give them a single cent in charitable contributions because that money is not spent on the developmentally disabled.  That money is used to pay bonuses for their executives.  If you must donate to an organization, donate to the Salvation Army.  93% of the donations the Salvation Army gets actually does go to support the cause of Salvation Army.  Easter Steals is a horrible, dreary, miserly place to work.  DID I MENTION, THERE ARE NO RAISES, unless you are executive staff.  What a terrible mistake it was working for this gulag.

cons:
Staff (teachers and paras) are ghetto and unprofessional-yelling profanities to pace and bus drivers in front of kids and other staff, half hour lunch-always feel rushed to eat. The worst part is that teachers and paras get stressed out & take it out on kids by locking them up in cubbies in the classroom or forcing them in dark rooms/exercise rooms when kids get out of control. 

Classroom environment is disruptive and kids cannot learn bc other kids are hitting, throwing, threatening staff etc. Easterseals is basically is a dump for parents to drop their kids off while they work bc these kids are not learning anything at this school with all the chaos that goes on. 

Typical day looks like: kids arrive off of bus, start aggression (hitting, kicking, biting), 3-4 staff members trying to control 1 kid/adult while other kids engage in maladaptive behaviors, then you are trying to get other kids ready for breakfast or lesson plan, then someone else engages in aggression etc. Cycle repeats and kids don't learn anything, and your basically acting like a shield blocking attacks all day. 

Many if not all of these kids have severe aggression so be ready to be overworked, unpaid, bruised and beat up by these kids/adults as they are extremely aggressive. I agree with other reviews that the upper management promotes from within/favoritism and they underpay their paras which many of them tend to be minorities like blacks and hispanics while all the therapists and teachers are white. Do not work here unless you don't mind the low pay and being overworked physically and mentally.

pros: I met a really great family, and I feel as though I am making a positive impact in their lives.
cons:
Everything. When I started I was told that I would get a call within a week to complete my training. It has now been 3 months and I have finally gotten an email that says, "training this friday, if you do not come you no longer work for this company." I received this email with less than a weeks notice, so I had to arrange my entire schedule. 

Another terrible thing: When I started at this company, during my interview, I was asked if I would work with clients outside of my county. I said that I would only work with clients in my county so that I did not have to drive an insanely far distance. There have been AT LEAST 7 instances that I have been scheduled outside of my county. One time I was scheduled OVER AN HOUR AWAY for 5 hours. I'm sorry, but I'm not going to drive an hour and a half to work somewhere for 5 hours at $9/hr. When I informed my supervisor of this, she said, "the schedule is set and you have to work where you are scheduled." There have been MANY other instances of this same thing; me being scheduled a crazy distance away. Why did they ask where I would work if it truly doesn't matter?

Another thing! When I started working for the family that I am with now, it took OVER A MONTH for my Easter Seals supervisor to send me the correct billing sheets and ISPs that were required for me to be in the home. I was just thrown in the home with no training, none of the correct paperwork, and no real experience in a home setting.

These are just a few reasons that I would encourage anyone looking to work in this field to go elsewhere. I LOVE what I do..I love making a difference in someones life, but I HATE the company that I go through. If you are looking to get into this field, I STRONGLY encourage you to look for another company.

cons: Poor leadership and management skills. The executive over the network  can't make a decision on her own yet is tasked with running majority of the company but can't come down off of her high horse long enough to acknowledge her staff. The exec team belittles and talks down to anyone that isn't a director a VP or a Cheif of whatever made up title they pull out of the cloud side note there is actually a VP of the cloud. pros: Easter Seals of Oregon administers grants to several communities who are in great need and working with these communities provide a great joy.
cons:
During the interview process, ESO (Easter Seals of Oregon) fails to mention that they operate as an "affiliate" of the National Easter Seals brand, which seems more than a little deceptive. 

Apart from the logo, ESO pretty much operates three primary programs, senior employment, veterans support, and a Latino job connection, under its own budget and authority. 

Strangely absent from their website are the ESO financials. Rather than outline what they contribute to the Oregon community, they rely only on the national statistics.

After ESO is awarded a grant, worker bees quickly become 'box checkers'. There is almost zero invested into the infrastructure or processes, and the equipment is outdated, even for a non-profit, thus creating a heavy load on the staff.

There is a lack of cohesive leadership from the top down. Micro management is confused with leadership. Managers are often overheard minimizing and criticizing other community agencies and the CEO who, according to management, got entangled with a younger woman who 'took' him to the cleaners and thus now impacts the overall budgets. Fact or fiction, this lack of professionalism does make it difficult to develop community partnerships as ESO is often "snubbed" by other more established agencies, and the staff has to spend an inordinate amount of energy in bridge building.

In less than one year, one program had more than a 73% turnover (national average is 16.6%). This is in large part due to the middle management, low pay compared to other agencies, and the lack of advancement opportunities - although there is an individual who did receive a promotion and a DECREASE in their salary.

ESO will not provide you with a career path but could be a good opportunity for those who are content with a 'worker bee' job. On the other hand, if you are someone who is looking to contribute to process improvements that impact the short and long term lives of the communities in need, you would do better to pass on ESO and look for an agency with a proven track record of compassion for the communities it services and the staff in which serves them.
